column1: Human-Like Sketch Object Recognition via Analogical Learning
Deep learning systems can perform well on some image recognition tasks. However
column3: including requiring far more training data than humans do and being fooled by adversarial examples. By contrast
column4: analogical learning over relational representations tends to be far more data-efficient
column5: requiring only human-like amounts of training data. This paper introduces an approach that combines automatically constructed qualitative visual representations with analogical learning to tackle a hard computer vision problem
column6: object recognition from sketches. Results from the MNIST dataset and a novel dataset
column8: are provided. Comparison to existing approaches indicates that analogical generalization can be used to identify sketched objects from these datasets with several orders of magnitude fewer examples than deep learning systems require.
